Some of our NPR colleagues have been traveling the U.S.-Mexico border - all of it, in fact.
MORNING EDITION's Steve Inskeep and several colleagues made plans for a drive from the mouth of the Rio Grande, on the Gulf of Mexico, all the way to Tijuana on the Pacific Coast.
And we're broadcasting their reports on people, goods and culture crossing the border on many NPR programs.
Steve is at NPR West in Southern California.
Hey there, Steve.
Hi, Audie.
So far, how is the trip?
How long is this trip again?
It is 1,900 miles and a little more along the U.S.-Mexico border, if you follow the border exactly.
But, of course, we were zigzagging back and forth across.
And I counted I crossed the border 22 times, going one way or another.
And it really was an amazing experience.
We were going through this zone that we called the borderland, the region both north and south of the border.
And, of course, the U.S.
and Mexico are very different places, but there's a lot of shared history and this common experience of the border itself.
That's what we wanted to learn more about.
And 22 times, I mean what's the border showing you about both countries?
Well, you have massive security on the border.
Audie, as you know, there are far stronger, higher and longer walls than there used to be.

And yet, in spite of that security, you find people who communicate, who have families on both sides, who travel back and forth, who do trade.
It's an extraordinarily busy zone for trade between these two countries.
You really do have a shared heritage as well as a shared present and a shared future in spite of the divisions.

The Reverend Jesse Jackson was a member of Martin Luther King Jr.'s inner circle.
Jackson would later become a key player in the civil rights movement.
We sat down with him this weekend to talk about what this legal victory meant to the overall struggle to attain equal rights for African-Americans.
Reverend Jackson also recounted a conversation he had with Mrs. Parks.
I asked Mrs. Parks one time, `Why didn't you go to the back of the bus?
You was facing loss of job, a life, a jail.
She said, `I thought about Emmett Till.
I couldn't go back.
And if Rosa Parks is metaphorically the mother of the modern civil rights movement, Thurgood Marshall would be the father of it.
Claudette Colvin and Emmett Till would have been the children of it.
Martin Luther King the prophet of it.
Our struggle is a struggle for legal protection and to end oppressive law.
Slavery was a set of laws, and many actions took place by heroic persons and by martyrs, but that system ended in 1865 with law.
And then there was a resistance to that system.
The big battle legally was the Supreme Court decision of 1954 led by Thurgood Marshall and, of course, Constance Baker Motley in Houston and Dr. Franklin and that team.

When the law changed in '54, a young lady named Claudette Colvin--she sat down March the 2nd in Montgomery, nine months before Rosa Parks, but she did not have the infrastructure of support that Rosa Parks had.
When Rosa Parks sat down December the 1st, she had met with attorney Fred Gray the day of December the 1st and days before that.
So when she sat down, she knew that she would be bailed out of jail.
There was a legal infrastructure in place.
Our poor Mrs. Parks, projected as this submissive silent little seamstress, in fact, was the opposite.
She was a bona fide freedom fighter.
Mrs. Parks joined the NAACP when she was 29 years old at the time when you would lose your job if you're a NAACP members, considered to be subversive.
You could not be a schoolteacher or a public employee and be a NAACP member during that time.
She meant to join the freedom movement.
She sought the right to vote in 1942.
They said she didn't pass a literacy test.
Well, she tried it again.
The second time they said, `You didn't pass the literacy test.
Third time they said she didn't pass it, she said, `I memorized the test and here are the questions and the answers.
She got her voting rights card in 1945.
Dr. King was only 16 years old at that time.
This was 10 years before Montgomery and 20 years before Selma.
So when she sat down, she was testing the legal case of 1954 and she won that legal case 13 months later.
So when people say movement, movement is a move or to end states' rights oppression, that in regular class federal intervention are for protection for all citizens.
Reverend, talk to me about the resolve that had to be of the people of Montgomery.
That's the interesting point that gets missed often and was there something about Montgomery?
Could this have happened anywhere?
It could have happened anywhere except that was a greater degree of organization in Montgomery, a relatively small town.
They had a bus boycott in Baton Rouge in '53, but didn't have the infrastructure of organization.
After all, Mrs. Parks had gone to Highlander Folk School and had studied civil rights, social and labor struggle.
She knew Ella Baker.
She knew A.
Philip Randolph.
E.D.
Nixon was a pullman porter.
So it was the degree of organization; she was NAACP secretary and NAACP youth director.
So what--continuously she was a seamstress.
She didn't get arrested for sewing.
She was a bona fide freedom fight.
So--and when you just said that when Mrs. Parks was arrested, you locked the wrong person up, they were not referring to a character which did not have limits.
They were saying, `You've now locked up the most famous resisting freedom fighter in town.'
Reverend, let me ask you this as relates to where we are today.
You not only steeped in knowledge, obviously, of the civil rights movement, but you were there.
You were part of it.
You were within the inner circle.
When you sit in 2005, are you happy?
Is this what you envisioned?
No.
We've changed the face of segregation; its heart is still pumping venom.
Its brains still thinks in states' rights terms.
The Brown v.
Board of Education wouldn't have won 9-to-zero with this Supreme Court.
This court would have sent that case back to Montgomery or back to Kansas.
So when Bush stacks the courts with states' rights judges at every level on up to the Supreme Court, there's a radical threat to workers, labor and civil rights.

So what is most threatening today is that, one, we seem to be not as aware of states' rights as we ought to be, number one, but, number two, that the civil rights struggles progress is very threatened today by--in '55, we could go to a higher court, to the federal government, to the Congress, to the Supreme Court to get relief.
Now the states' rights control the House and Senate, Supreme Court and the White House.
So they are poised to take back virtually every right gained in the last 50 years.
Where are we in Alabama, a state 35 percent black in year 2005?
Alabama blacks incarcerated five times the rate of whites.
Fourteen percent of Alabama voting-age population, blacks are disenfranchised.
They've been to jail and can't vote no more.
Twenty-five percent of black males are incarcerated.
Nineteen appellate judges; zero black.
Fifteen federal judges; two black.
Two hundred and twenty Alabama judges; 16 are black.
The district attorneys, 40; zero black.
Sheriffs, 67; eight are black.

So the gap between blacks and whites on the buses have been eliminated, but the gaps in the judicial system and the educational system, those gaps, in fact, are--not only are they wide but they're not being decisively resisted.
It is as if we were embarrassed by the signs.
The signs of `color' and `white' were certainly very visible signs that were humiliating to African-Americans and embarrassing to whites at some point.
When those signs came down, it only changed the signs, not the infrastructure.
So you end slavery, but those who gain benefits from being slave--master didn't lose any property.
They didn't lose anything.
So you look at the private sector.
You look at credit exploitation, the banks and CRA(ph), ownership of radio or TV and beverage and construction companies.
You see just how much further we have to go, and I think we must measure because our struggle is not just for freedom; it is for equality.
Our struggle is for equality.
Are we misguided with the notion that when we were struggling in the '50s and '60s, there was a struggle for a collective movement of people to reach a certain point?
Now it seems as though there are individuals who are allowed to move, but the collective seems stalled.
Well, the system always let a few people through, and it is our struggle to get equal protection under the law for all Americans.
Our struggle remains a collective struggle to end race discrimination, whether you are black skin or dark skin, PhD or no D, there's the race spotlight on your back.
That was Reverend Jesse Jackson, president of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition.
